questions.question_text:
You enable controlled folder access in audit mode for several computers that run Windows 10.
You need to review the events audited by controlled folder access.
Which Event Viewer log should you view?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The following controlled folder access events appear in Windows Event Viewer under Microsoft/Windows/Windows Defender/Operational folder.
source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/evaluate-controlled-folder-access?view=o365-worldwide

choices.B: From the Start menu, select Group Policy Object Editor.
choices.A: From PowerShell, run the Get-GPO cmdlet.
choices.C: From a command prompt, run scanstate and specify the /genconfig parameter.
choices.D: From a command prompt, run gpresult and specify the /H parameter.

discussion.content:
In the real exam you'll this choice:
From Microsoft Edge, open edge://policy

Selected Answer: D
A: Shows you GPO's but nothing locally set
B: Start the GPO Editor but shows nothing locally set
C: scanstate has nothing to do with GPO's are settings
D: Shows you a /h = humanly readable overview of the policies that are active on your system

The "Get-GPO" cmdlet from PowerShell is the better solution for generating a report that contains all the Microsoft Edge policy settings applied to a computer. This cmdlet is specifically designed for querying Group Policy Objects in a Windows environment and provides detailed information about each policy, including those that have been applied to Microsoft Edge.
On the other hand, the "gpresult" command with the "/H" parameter is a general-purpose command that provides information about the policies applied to a computer, but it may not provide as much detail as the Get-GPO cmdlet. Additionally, "gpresult" is an older tool that is not specifically designed for querying GPOs in a Windows environment, and its functionality is limited compared to the newer "Get-GPO" cmdlet.
In conclusion, if you need to generate a report that contains all the Microsoft Edge policy settings applied to a computer, it is recommended to use the "Get-GPO" cmdlet from PowerShell for more accurate and detailed results.

comments.content:
Actually A is completely wrong.

We need to get the LGPO as well, I forgot to read again the statement in the question: "and local Group Policy Objects (GPOs)".

D will be right and complete.

Considering that this cmdlet is exclusive for domain, you might be right about this answer.

source: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/grouppolicy/get-gpo?view=windowsserver2019-ps

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
since "edge://policy" is not an option I'll go with D

Selected Answer: D
I vote for D

The Get-GPOReport cmdlet is "for a specified Group Policy Object (GPO) or for all GPOs in a domain."
This doesn't include local policy. I believe answer should be D.

Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/grouppolicy/get-gporeport?view=windowsserver2022-ps

comments.content: I agree, also the second time I see this question on examtopics and there it was 'D' as well.

discussion.content:
Resposta Correta: D 

Gpresult [/x | /h] <filename> - Salva o relatório no formato XML (/x) ou HTML (/h) no local e com o nome do arquivo especificado pelo parâmetro filename.

Referência:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/gpresult

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain. The domain contains 1,000 computers that run Windows 10.
You configure Microsoft Edge settings by using domain and local Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
You need to generate a report that contains all the Microsoft Edge policy settings applied to a computer.
What should you do?

discussion.content: Does it really matter between Pro and Enterprise?

comments.content: nevermind, can't go from Home to Enterprise

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a computer named Client1 that runs Windows 11 Home.
You need to ensure that you can create virtual machines on Client1.
Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Statements
Computer1 can use Application Guard in Enterprise-managed mode. Yes
Computer2 can copy clipboard settings from Microsoft Edge to Application Guard. No
Computer3 can download files from Application Guard to the host operating system. Yes

Explanation:

Computer1 (Windows 10 Enterprise) can use Application Guard in Enterprise-managed mode because the "Turn on Windows Defender Application Guard in Managed Mode" setting is enabled and this computer has the required edition of Windows.

Computer2 (Windows 10 Pro) cannot copy clipboard settings from Microsoft Edge to Application Guard because the "Configure Windows Defender Application Guard clipboard settings" setting is enabled and this computer is not running Windows 10 Enterprise edition.

Computer3 (Windows 10 Pro) can download files from Application Guard to the host operating system because the "Allow files to download and save to the host operating system from Windows Defender Application Guard" setting is enabled.

comments.content:
It's Yes, No Yes. 

Flabezerra's link won't show you the answers, just the general location of where the answers are.

discussion.content:
YES NO YES

Computer2 won't be able to use clipboard because it is a Windows Pro.

Clipboard is effective only in managed mode. Application Guard in managed mode is only available for W10 Enterprise or W11.

Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Microsoft Defender Application Guard\Configure Microsoft Defender Application Guard clipboard settings
Supported on: "At least Windows 10 enterprise"

Study the reference below:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/microsoft-defender-application-guard/md-app-guard-overview
System requirements;
Install Application Guard;
Configure Application Guard policies;
and Test scenarios.

comments.content:
Thanks for the link, but it includes Pro:
Allow files to download to host operating system Windows 10 Enterprise or Pro, 1803 or higher
Windows 11 Enterprise or Pro

Determines whether to save downloaded files to the host operating system from the Microsoft Defender Application Guard container. Enabled. This is effective only in managed mode. Allows users to save downloaded files from the Microsoft Defender Application Guard container to the host operating system. This action creates a share between the host and container that also allows for uploads from the host to the Application Guard container.
Disabled or not configured. Users aren't able to save downloaded files from Application Guard to the host operating system.

Should be Yes, Yes, No
Windows 10 pro cannot download to host operating system view the link below

To add a custom environment variable that is present when another user signs in to the computer, you should add User1 to the "Administrators" group, which has the necessary permissions to set system-wide environment variables.

User1 can use the System Properties app to add the environment variable

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a computer that runs Windows 10 and contains two users named User1 and User2.

User1 needs to add a custom environment variable. The variable must be present when User2 signs in to the computer. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.

To which group should you add User1, and what should User1 use to add the environment variable? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point

//IMG//
